In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.          INTRODUCTION 
 
1.   In  January  2012,  the  Department  of  Finance–National  Credit  Council  (DOF–NCC) 
asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
to develop microinsurance in the Philippines and promote financial inclusion. The government 
requested  ADB  to  follow  up  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  Developing 
Microinsurance Project completed in September 2012 .1 The fact-finding mission was conducted 
from 18 to 20 July 2012 in conjunction with the review mission for the JFPR grant. The DOF–
NCC (the government’s executing agency) and the Insurance Commission (the government’s 
implementing  agency)  agreed  on  the  proposed  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference as laid out in the approved 
concept paper. Although the proposed TA was not included in the country operations business 
plan, 2010–20122 under the country partnership strategy, 2011–20163 for the Philippines, the 
concept paper was approved by the Vice-President of Operations 2 on 27 September 2012 in 
view of the benefits for low-income households in terms of social safety net and disaster risk 
financing  supported  by  the  public–private  partnership  approach.  The  project  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Background.  ADB  has  been  one  of  the  few  very  active  development  partners  for 
microfinance  development  in  the  Philippines,  and  has  contributed  to  the  growth  of  formal 
microfinance activities. After several TA projects ADB approved the Microfinance Development 
Program5  whose  objectives  included  expanding  the  outreach  of  diversified  formal  financial 
services to poor clients at the most affordable cost. Increased microfinance activities for  poor 
clients has the risk of making them worse off through unexpected events, unless some form of 
safety net can be provided through microinsurance. This gave rise to the formulation of the 
JFPR grant, approved in 2008, to complement efforts under the Microfinance Development 
Program  to  further  financial  inclusion.  It  was  the  first  ADB  intervention  focusing  on 
microinsurance development. The grant was completed in September 2012. The following are 
major achievements under the JFPR grant: 
    
3.  Improving regulatory framework. While the National Strategy for Microinsurance was 
formulated  with  support  from  German  development  cooperation  through  GIZ  International 
Services, the regulatory framework and performance standards were revised and enhanced 
under the grant to facilitate private sector participation (targeting the supply side). Following the 
approval of the Regulatory Framework for Microinsurance by government authorities in 2010, 
pertinent Insurance Commission circulars were issued after a series of consultative discussions 
at the technical working group (TWG) involving a wide range of stakeholders from both the 
public and private sectors. DOF–NCC, the Insurance Commission, the Securities and Exchange 
Commission, and the Cooperative Development Authority coordinated the efforts through a joint 
steering committee to implement the regulations and issued joint circulars for formalization of 
the microinsurance sector.6

4.  Strengthening  the  capacity  of  government  regulators  and  microinsurance 
providers.  The  microinsurance  regulations,  pertinent  rules,  and  performance  standards 
developed under the grant were disseminated to the public and stakeholders, particularly to 
insurance providers licensed by the Insurance Commission. Training materials, including the 
performance standards compliance procedures, were developed and institutionalized through 
the concerned TWG and training sessions were conducted for insurance providers. The training 
also included preparation of the revised annual statements (to include microinsurance data) to 
be submitted by the insurance providers to the commission. 
  
5.  Promoting financial literacy on microinsurance. A Roadmap to Financial Literacy on 
Microinsurance7  was  adopted  and  a  nationwide  advocacy  campaign  has  been  under 
implementation  since  2011  (approach  to  the  demand  side).  From  a  very  early  stage  of 
development, signs of increased demand for microinsurance products and services have been 
positive, and a growing confidence exists in the role of the microfinance industry to achieve 
inclusive finance. The advocacy campaign was initially designed on a pilot basis, but expanded 
to  the  regional  level  with  support  from  German  development  cooperation  through  GIZ 
International Services. 
 
6.  In  line  with  ADB’s  Integrated  Disaster  Risk  Management  Program,8  insurance 
protection—especially  microinsurance  for  low-income  households—has  been  identified  an 
effective ex ante disaster risk finance tool. The proposed TA links the  JFPR grant (footnote 1) 
and  the  Disaster  Risk  Financing  Project  programmed  for  2015,  which  will  involve 
microinsurance service for disaster risks  as one of the major components of the ensuing loan. 
Some of the prerequisite work will be carried out under the TA. 
 
7.  The following are the key remaining issues identified to be covered under the TA. 
 
8.  Insufficient  level  playing  field  for  microinsurance  providers.  The  definition  of 
microinsurance product has been formulated and the product registration requirement has been 
implemented under the regulation. For microinsurance products, a level playing field has been 
established for all microinsurance providers, regardless of the form of the entities, and reliable 
statistics have been made available. However, the current regulation remains vague in certain 
aspects of capital requirements, which risks regulatory arbitrage. Under the JFPR grant, a two-
tier approach was taken to allow more concessional capital requirements, mainly for emerging 
mutual benefit associations, which encouraged them to cater especially to poor clients.  
  
9.  Lack  of  capacity  to  develop  new microinsurance  products. The microinsurance 
sector  started  mainly  with  simple  and  easy-to-understand  products. With  expansion  of the 
sector,  innovative  products  like  parametric-  or  index-type  insurance  products  have  been 
introduced on a pilot basis. The capacity of the supervisors needs to be enhanced to catch up 
with these new developments, specifically to review the products properly and issue approvals 
on a timely basis.   
 
10.  Need  for  more  efficient  distribution  network.  Microinsurance  development  still 
depends on its traditional distribution network, including agents, although ADB’s support for 
microfinance  development  enabled  microfinance  institutions  and  community-based 
organizations (nongovernment organizations, mutual benefit associations, and cooperatives) to 
play active roles as delivery channels. Efficient administration costs, in addition to pure risk

8  ADB. 2012. Regional and Sustainable Development Department Briefing Note; ADB’s Integrated Disaster Risk

3 
premium,  will  determine  the  affordability  of  products to  low-income  people. The  Insurance 
Commission  should  promote  the  development  of  cost-effective  administration,  including 
paperless contracts via mobile, e-payments for both premiums and claims, and engagement of 
a broader range of intermediaries (e.g., points of sale, pharmacies, and remittance centers). 
The  Insurance  Commission  should  create  the  regulatory  environment  enabling  these 
innovations through amendments to current regulations or timely issuance of new ones. 
 
11.  Inadequate consumer protection scheme for microinsurance business. At this early 
stage of microinsurance development, consumers are beginning to see challenges in terms of 
consumer protection. These need to be tackled in a more systematic manner. Mainly because 
of the nature of many small transactions, the traditional dispute resolution scheme will not be 
appropriate for the microinsurance business. Filing in court is too expensive for low-income 
households and filing complaints with the authorities does not provide enough accessibility for 
the policyholders. Many policyholders are low-income households in rural areas that require 
more  simplified  and  affordable  alternative  dispute  resolution  mechanisms.  The  discussion 
among stakeholders started in May 2012 but the Insurance Commission needs further support 
for drafting regulations and their implementation. 
 
12.  Further need for financial literacy at local government unit level. Under the JFPR 
grant, a Roadmap to Financial Literacy on Microinsurance was adopted and the first nationwide 
financial literacy campaign was conducted at the regional level (footnote 7). The response to 
date has been positive but this campaign should be extended to the local government unit (LGU) 
level. Based on the assessment of the impacts by the first campaign, including a pilot project in 
Quezon City, the program will have to better suit the needs of the LGUs in terms of modality and 
delivery mechanism. 
 
13.  Sustaining momentum on coordinated activities among stakeholders. One of the 
key success factors for the grant was effective coordination among stakeholders, led by the joint 
steering committee and TWGs. For example, DOF, the Insurance Commission, the Securities 
and Exchange Commission, and the Cooperative Development Authority issued a joint circular 
based on consultation under these groups. The TA will provide technical support to those 
activities, including seminars and workshops. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The  impact  will  be  more  affordable  contingent  risk  insurance  among  low-income 
households, including climate change and natural disasters. The outcome will be an expanded 
microinsurance market, in terms of market size and number of players. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  Output 1: Improved level playing field for microinsurance providers. A diagnostic 
study on the challenges faced by microinsurance providers, including a risk-based supervisory 
and monitoring system, will be conducted with support from the TA consultants. While new 
regulations on risk-based capital requirements will be prepared with inputs from TA consultants, 
the  enabling  environment  for  small  microinsurance  providers  should  be  maintained.  A

4 
providers through the workshops, and the draft government regulations should reflect various 
stakeholders’ views. 
 
16.  Output  2:  Improved  capacity  to  develop  new  microinsurance  products. A gap 
analysis of capacity development of regulators for new microinsurance products, including index 
and parametric types, will be conducted. Based on the results, a capacity development plan will 
be formulated with support from the TA consultants. Required training for regulators by TA 
consultants will follow.   
 
17.  Output 3: More efficient distribution network. Innovative distribution networks, like 
mobile payments and e-payment, involve jurisdictions other than the financial sector. The review 
of the current regulatory environment should be necessary to enable innovations including 
cashless transactions. Consultations among concerned government agencies are essential to 
identify areas where amendments are needed, and to issue new ones on a timely basis. The TA 
will  support  a  review  of  the  current  regulatory  environment  and  the  preparation  of  new 
regulations. 
 
18.  Output 4: Established consumer protection scheme for microinsurance business. 
In view of the limited access to and capacity of the formal dispute resolution system, the 
enforceable market conducts for microinsurance providers  with proper system for handling 
customer complaints by microinsurance providers themselves are necessary to improve the 
access. The monitoring and reporting system backed by regulations will be formulated with 
support  from  the  TA.  This  will  be  based  on  an  understanding  between  regulators  and 
microinsurance  providers  that  consumer  protection  is  essential  for  development  of  the 
microinsurance business. 
 
19.  Output 5: Enhanced financial literacy campaign formulated at local government 
unit level and production of knowledge products. An impact assessment on the national 
financial literacy campaign during 2011–2012 under the JFPR grant, including a pilot project 
with Quezon City government, will be conducted and the analysis on the area where further 
intervention is needed at LGU level to expand the coverage. A knowledge and communication 
plan will be developed, with contents, target group, and delivery means identified. The results of 
the  impact  assessment  and  draft  knowledge  and  communication  plan  will  be  shared  and 
discussed with the concerned stakeholders for implementation.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the JFPR and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support 
in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years, from March 2013 to March 2016. DOF–NCC 
will be the executing agency, while the Insurance Commission will be the implementing agency. 
This  is  the  same  arrangement  as for the JFPR  grant.  For  the  implementation  of training, 
seminars,  and  conferences  proposed  under  the  TA,  an  advance  payment  facility  will  be 
established at the executing agency. 
 
22.  The  project  requires  a  diverse  mix  of  experts  (four  international  consultants  with 
18 person-months of inputs and five national consultants with 96 person-months of inputs), with

5 
expertise in microinsurance business development, insurance supervision, consumer protection, 
information, education, communication, and financial literacy. Because of the specialized nature 
of the assignments, it is difficult to identify a sufficient number of consulting firms that could 
assemble a high-quality team of experts. Therefore, individual consultants will be recruited. The 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement will be done in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) for the production of 
materials.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The eligibility or 
ineligibility  of  expenditures  will  be  guided  by  JFPR  policies  and  guidelines  for  technical 
assistance. 9 The consultants’ terms of reference are outlined in Appendix 3. 
 
23.  In addition to the main outputs, the consultants will submit to ADB and the executing 
agency (i) an inception report 1 month after commencement of services; (ii) interim progress 
reports at appropriate stages during TA implementation; (iii) the draft summary final report for 
the overall TA before the conclusion of the contract; and (iv) a revised final report 1 month after 
receiving and taking into account the comments of, and feedback from, the executing agency, 
other stakeholders, and ADB. 
 
24.  The executing agency and ADB review missions will regularly monitor and report on 
major  project  activities.  Consultants’ reports  will  be  presented  in  workshops  and  seminars 
organized for the validation of findings. Reports will be made available on ADB websites and 
published whenever warranted for the meetings for stakeholders. Knowledge products will be 
developed and disseminated as planned.  
 
25.  The TA will also support stakeholders’ consultations on issues related to microinsurance 
through the platform established under the JFPR grant, the joint steering committee, and the 
TWGs to maintain the capacity of coordinated efforts among stakeholders. The joint steering 
committee  and  the  TWGs  have  proven  to  be  very  effective,  not  only  to  intake  various 
stakeholders’ views but also to disseminate the results of TA activities.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of the Philippines to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Capacity Building for Microinsurance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (18 person-months) 
 
1.  Microinsurance business development specialist  (team leader, 8 person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist should have a postgraduate degree in insurance or finance and at 
least  8  years  professional  experience,  including  experience  in  the  development  of 
microinsurance products and services. Experience in Southeast Asia is preferred.  
 
2.  Working with the project management unit (PMU) and project implementation unit (PIU) 
and under the guidance of the steering committee, the specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct a comprehensive review of the current insurance regulatory framework 
to support the development of microinsurance to meet the risk protection needs 
of low-income households; 
(ii)  identify the regulatory impediments for the development of microinsurance in 
terms of innovative product development, transaction of payment and efficient 
distribution channel, and provide recommendations for revisions; 
(iii)  develop draft implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) to achieve an improved 
regulatory environment, with support from the national regulation specialist; 
(iv)  formulate the implementation plan of the reform, with steps and time lines, as a 
recommendation to the PMU and PIU; 
(v)  conduct gap analysis of the capacity and resources of the Insurance Commission 
for innovative product development, including index and parametric type products, 
and facilitate a self-diagnostic study by the Insurance Commission; 
(vi)  assist the Insurance Commission to draft the capacity and resource development 
plan to fill the gaps; 
(vii)  guide and manage the inputs of other consultants; take the lead responsibility for 
the preparation of the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, draft final, and final 
reports, incorporating as appropriate contributions from other consultants; and 
(viii)  prepare the inception, interim, end of project, and periodic progress reports as 
required by the PMU and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
3.  Insurance  supervision  specialist  (4  person-months,  intermittent).  The  specialist 
should have a postgraduate degree in banking or insurance and at least 5 years professional 
experience, including experience in the supervision of an insurance business. Experience in 
Southeast Asia is preferred. 
 
4.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the 
specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct a study on the current insurance regulatory framework on solvency and 
risk management issues, including the minimum capital requirement and the 
solvency margin monitoring; 
(ii)  recommend the necessary revisions to create a level playing field in terms of 
capital management for a whole range of microinsurance service providers; 
(iii)  formulate  and  design  the  information  technology  based  on-site  and  off-site 
supervision  system  with  manuals,  and  incorporate  the  inputs  from  the 
consultation with relevant stakeholders, including the Insurance Commission and 
industry; and 
(iv)  assist the team leader in preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, and 
periodic progress reports as required by the PMU and ADB.

Appendix 3       11 
5.  Consumer protection specialist (3 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should 
have at least 5 years hands-on experience in the dispute resolution framework. The specialist 
should  also  have  working  knowledge  of  the  legal  frameworks  established  internationally, 
including alternative dispute resolution, and will be conversant in supporting legislation. Working 
experience in a relevant financial industry is an advantage. 
 
6.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the 
specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review the consumer protection framework, mainly translation aspects including 
contract wordings, with support from the financial sector regulation specialist; 
(ii)  formulate and design efficient and effective consumer protection mechanisms for 
small-scale  transactions,  including  microfinance  or  microinsurance,  in 
consultation with relevant stakeholders; 
(iii)  recommend steps to be taken, including revision of the regulatory framework; 
and 
(iv)  assist the team leader in preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, and 
periodic progress reports as required by the PMU and ADB. 
 
7.  Information,  education,  and  communication  specialist  (3  person-months, 
intermittent).  The  specialist  should  have  at  least  5  years  professional  experience  in  the 
academe and/or hands-on experience in developing and implementing large-scale information, 
education,  and  communication  (IEC)  and  advocacy  programs,  especially  involving  rural 
communities. A degree in mass communications or related fields is an advantage. 
 
8.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the 
specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct  impact  assessments  on  the  national  financial  literacy  campaign  for 
2011–2012 and analyze where further intervention is needed; 
(ii)  develop a knowledge and communications plan with contents, target group, and 
delivery means identified; 
(iii)  develop various IEC and advocacy strategies and programs, specifically and 
collectively targeted at relevant stakeholders including local government units 
(LGUs);  
(iv)  determine  the  optimum  and  cost-effective  dissemination  and/or  mass  media 
methodologies, considering the specific and collective target groups for the IEC 
and advocacy programs to be developed; 
(v)  assist in the rollout and initial implementation of the respective IEC and advocacy 
programs  by  the  PMU  and  PIU  and  microinsurance  providers  and  other 
stakeholders; and 
(vi)  assist the team leader in the preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, 
and periodic progress reports as required by the PMU and ADB. 
 
B.  National Consultants (96 person-months) 
 
9.  Microinsurance development specialist (deputy team leader, 36 person-months). The 
specialist should have at least 7 years professional experience in the academe (banking and 
finance) and/or experience in a management position, preferably with a large microinsurance 
provider with over 10,000 clients. A degree in banking and finance or related fields  is an 
advantage.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
10.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the 
specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  assist in all aspects of and provide back-up support to the international team 
leader in relation to the terms of reference; 
(ii)  assist in supervising the day-to-day operations of the team and ensuring that 
work schedules and milestones are monitored and accomplished; 
(iii)  undertake  other  tasks  needed  for  the  efficient  implementation  of  consulting 
support to the PMU and PIU that may be reasonably required by the team leader; 
and 
(iv)  contribute as required to the preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, 
and periodic progress reports. 
 
11.  Financial sector regulation specialist (4 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
should have extensive knowledge of and at least 5 years hands-on experience in legal and 
regulatory frameworks, enabling development of the financial sector, including the insurance 
sector. A working knowledge of legal frameworks established internationally with supporting 
legislation is an advantage.   
 
12.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the 
specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  assist the team leader to design an improved insurance regulatory environment; 
(ii)  assist  the  insurance  supervision  specialist  to  review  the  current  insurance 
regulatory framework on solvency and risk management issues, including the 
minimum capital requirement and the solvency margin monitoring; 
(iii)  assist  the  consumer  protection  specialist  to  review  the  consumer  protection 
framework and develop the implementation plan; 
(iv)  provide the necessary assistance to the executing and implementing agencies 
for drafting implementing rules and regulations; and 
(v)  contribute as required to the preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, 
and periodic progress reports. 
 
13.  Microinsurance business specialist (8 person months, intermittent). The specialist 
should have at least 5 years of professional and/or hands-on experience, including at least 
2 years  at  a  senior  level  position  of  a  financial  institution  engaged  in  microinsurance  or 
insurance  and/or  the  academe.  Experience  in  managing  donor-funded  capacity  building 
technical assistance projects, and a degree in finance and insurance or related fields are 
advantages. 
 
14.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the 
microinsurance business specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  assist the team leader and deputy team leader in all aspects of the terms of 
reference as required; 
(ii)  coordinate and collect reports for submission to the PMU and/or the steering 
committee, in cooperation with the PMU and PIU; 
(iii)  assist the consumer protection specialist to formulate and design efficient and 
effective consumer protection mechanisms for small-scale transactions, including 
microfinance or microinsurance, in consultation with relevant stakeholders; 
(iv)  assist the PMU and PIU to implement recommended necessary steps by the 
consumer protection specialist for consumer protection, including revision of the 
regulatory framework;

Appendix 3       13 
(v)  undertake other tasks that may be reasonably required by the team leader for the 
efficient operation of the PMU, especially providing technical support to the PMU 
and the steering committee; and 
(vi)  contribute as required to the preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, 
and periodic progress reports. 
 
15.  Financial literacy specialist (12 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should 
have a degree in business administration, finance, or a related field, and at least 5 years 
professional experience in microfinance, including 3 years experience in financial literacy; and a 
good understanding of microinsurance in the Philippines. Experience in managing donor-funded 
capacity building technical assistance projects and a degree in finance and insurance or related 
fields are advantages. 
 
16.  Working with the PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee, the specialist 
will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  assist the team leader and deputy team leader in all aspects of the terms of 
reference as required; 
(ii)  work with the information, education, and communication specialist on financial 
literacy to propose recommendations for addressing gaps identified, taking into 
consideration international best practice; 
(iii)  support the conduct of a gap analysis of existing financial literacy among low-
income populations and a goal for financial literacy; 
(iv)  undertake other tasks that may be reasonably required by the team leader for the 
efficient operation of the PMU, especially providing technical support to the PMU 
and the steering committee; and 
(v)  contribute as required to the preparation of the inception, interim, end of project, 
and periodic progress reports. 
 
17.  National project assistant (36 person-months). The assistant should have a degree in 
business administration, economics, or a related discipline and at least 3 years professional 
experience in the areas of project assistance and management. Experience in managing donor-
funded capacity building technical assistance projects and a degree in finance and insurance or 
related fields are advantages. 
 
18.  Working with the PMU and PIU and under the guidance of the steering committee,  the 
assistant will perform the following tasks:
 
(i)  assist  in  arranging  and  organizing  meetings  for  the  TA  activities  and  ADB 
missions; 
(ii)  coordinate and collect reports for submission to the PMU and/or the steering 
committee, in cooperation with the PIU; 
(iii)  assist in preparing materials for reports, meetings, and workshops, including 
materials and document production; 
(iv)  undertake other tasks that may be reasonably required by the team leader for the 
efficient operation of the PMU, especially providing technical support to the PMU 
and the steering committee; and 
(v)  contribute as required to the preparation of periodic progress, interim, and end of 
project reports.
